en.value: Talking about our essential personal items, revising adjectives and quantifiers - The verb "to have"
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
"Phone" can refer to any type of phone, whether it's portable or not. When we talk about portable phones, we say "mobile (phone)" in British English, and "cell (phone)" in American English.
British English: Can I use your mobile?
American English: Can you pass me my cell?
Choose the word that matches the image.
We use "computer" as a general word for all computers, but we also use "laptop" to refer to portable computers.
I'm reading a really good book.
This word refers to a portable computer.
Match the beginning and the end of the sentences.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Oh, yes! Thank you so much!
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
Select the words in the correct order.
Fill in the gap using the image.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
What do you have in your bag? Write or record your answer.
"To have" is a very common verb in English. We can use it in lots of different ways, but for now, we are going to use it to talk about our family and personal possessions.
Select the form of the verb "to have" in each sentence.
We use "have" with nearly all personal pronouns in the present tense. The only exception is "he / she / it", where we use "has".
To talk about things that we don't possess, we add the verb "do" to the sentence. The correct sentence order is "do / does" + "not" + "have".
We always use "have" in negative sentences with all personal pronouns. It's just "do / does" that changes with "he / she / it".
To form questions about possessions, we simply add "do" or "does" (for "he / she / it" only) to the beginning of the sentence. Again, "have" does not change.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
